rev.diff:
Line 61: Line 61:
<p>
<p>
Sight gags, sound effects, and musical montages abound, as do intriguing possibilities of what's possible with the new combined technology of color, sound, film cuts, and video effects. A repairman works with a screwdriver on thin air, and, when done, flips a invisible switch — a television screen (showing, of course, a western) materializes out of nowhere, then vanishes when the repairman flips the unseen switch off. Marble statues come to life, then crumble to pieces. A maid sucks up pieces of crumpled paper with an invisible vacuum cleaner.
Sight gags, sound effects, and musical montages abound, as do intriguing possibilities of what's possible with the new combined technology of color, sound, film cuts, and video effects. A repairman works with a screwdriver on thin air, and, when done, flips a invisible switch — a television screen (showing, of course, a western) materializes out of nowhere, then vanishes when the repairman flips the unseen switch off. Marble statues come to life, then crumble to pieces. A maid sucks up pieces of crumpled paper with an invisible vacuum cleaner.
â
[[Image: ernie milktable.jpg|thumb|125px|center|Milk missing the cup]]
+
<!-- [[Image: ernie milktable.jpg|thumb|125px|center|Milk missing the cup]] -->
<p><br>
<p><br>
Throughout, Eugene, at worst, is only mildly perplexed -- at least until the end, when, seated at the side of a long table, he finds the contents of his lunchbox keep rolling away, a plumb-bobbed plum is at an angle off vertical, and milk from a thermos misses the cup directly below it. A photo of how the 'tilted table' trick was done is available [http://kinescopehd.blogspot.com/2010/02/portrait-of-genius-in-black-white.html | here|].
Throughout, Eugene, at worst, is only mildly perplexed -- at least until the end, when, seated at the side of a long table, he finds the contents of his lunchbox keep rolling away, a plumb-bobbed plum is at an angle off vertical, and milk from a thermos misses the cup directly below it. A photo of how the 'tilted table' trick was done is available [http://kinescopehd.blogspot.com/2010/02/portrait-of-genius-in-black-white.html | here|].
<br><br>
<br><br>
  +
== Critical Reception ==
== Critical Reception ==
In 1957, Ernie Kovacs received the Sylvania Award<ref name="Syl">The Sylvania Award was issued between 1952 and 1958 to those who made a significant contribution to the American television industry. See an example: [http://uv201.com/TV_Pages/sylvania_award.htm |Sylvania award 1952 webpage of the "Reverse Time Page" website]</ref> for his work on the 1957 NBC special.<ref name="MusTV" />

See an example: [http://uv201.com/TV_Pages/sylvania_award.htm |Sylvania award 1952 webpage of the "Reverse Time Page" website]</ref> for his work on the 1957 NBC special.<ref name="MusTV" />
